apiDescription: The size of this primitive is how many bytes it takes to reference any location in memory. For example, on a 32 bit target, this is 4 bytes and on a 64 bit target, this is 8 bytes.

methods.name: pub const fn min_value() -> isize

description: Returns the smallest value that can be represented by this integer type.

methods.name: pub const fn max_value() -> isize

description: Returns the largest value that can be represented by this integer type.

methods.name: pub fn from_str_radix(src: &str, radix: u32) -> Result<isize, ParseIntError>

description: Converts a string slice in a given base to an integer.
The string is expected to be an optional + or - sign followed by digits. Leading and trailing whitespace represent an error. Digits are a subset of these characters, depending on radix:
0-9 a-z A-Z
Panics
This function panics if radix is not in the range from 2 to 36.

methods.name: pub const fn count_ones(self) -> u32

description: Returns the number of ones in the binary representation of self.

methods.name: pub const fn count_zeros(self) -> u32

description: Returns the number of zeros in the binary representation of self.

methods.name: pub const fn leading_zeros(self) -> u32

description: Returns the number of leading zeros in the binary representation of self.

methods.name: pub const fn trailing_zeros(self) -> u32

description: Returns the number of trailing zeros in the binary representation of self.

methods.name: pub const fn rotate_left(self, n: u32) -> isize

description: Shifts the bits to the left by a specified amount, n, wrapping the truncated bits to the end of the resulting integer.
Please note this isn't the same operation as <<!

methods.name: pub const fn rotate_right(self, n: u32) -> isize

description: Shifts the bits to the right by a specified amount, n, wrapping the truncated bits to the beginning of the resulting integer.
Please note this isn't the same operation as >>!

methods.name: pub const fn swap_bytes(self) -> isize

description: Reverses the byte order of the integer.

methods.name: pub const fn reverse_bits(self) -> isize
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (reverse_bits #48763)

methods.name: pub const fn from_be(x: isize) -> isize

description: Converts an integer from big endian to the target's endianness.
On big endian this is a no-op. On little endian the bytes are swapped.

methods.name: pub const fn from_le(x: isize) -> isize

description: Converts an integer from little endian to the target's endianness.
On little endian this is a no-op. On big endian the bytes are swapped.

methods.name: pub const fn to_be(self) -> isize

description: Converts self to big endian from the target's endianness.
On big endian this is a no-op. On little endian the bytes are swapped.

methods.name: pub const fn to_le(self) -> isize

description: Converts self to little endian from the target's endianness.
On little endian this is a no-op. On big endian the bytes are swapped.

methods.name: pub fn checked_add(self, rhs: isize) -> Option<isize>

description: Checked integer addition. Computes self + rhs, returning None if overflow occurred.

methods.name: pub fn checked_sub(self, rhs: isize) -> Option<isize>

description: Checked integer subtraction. Computes self - rhs, returning None if overflow occurred.

methods.name: pub fn checked_mul(self, rhs: isize) -> Option<isize>

description: Checked integer multiplication. Computes self * rhs, returning None if overflow occurred.

methods.name: pub fn checked_div(self, rhs: isize) -> Option<isize>

description: Checked integer division. Computes self / rhs, returning None if rhs == 0 or the division results in overflow.

methods.name: pub fn checked_div_euc(self, rhs: isize) -> Option<isize>
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn checked_rem(self, rhs: isize) -> Option<isize>

description: Checked integer remainder. Computes self % rhs, returning None if rhs == 0 or the division results in overflow.

methods.name: pub fn checked_mod_euc(self, rhs: isize) -> Option<isize>
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn checked_neg(self) -> Option<isize>

description: Checked negation. Computes -self, returning None if self == MIN.

methods.name: pub fn checked_shl(self, rhs: u32) -> Option<isize>

description: Checked shift left. Computes self << rhs, returning None if rhs is larger than or equal to the number of bits in self.

methods.name: pub fn checked_shr(self, rhs: u32) -> Option<isize>

description: Checked shift right. Computes self >> rhs, returning None if rhs is larger than or equal to the number of bits in self.

methods.name: pub fn checked_abs(self) -> Option<isize>

description: Checked absolute value. Computes self.abs(), returning None if self == MIN.

methods.name: pub fn checked_pow(self, exp: u32) -> Option<isize>
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (no_panic_pow #48320)

methods.name: pub fn saturating_add(self, rhs: isize) -> isize

description: Saturating integer addition. Computes self + rhs, saturating at the numeric bounds instead of overflowing.

methods.name: pub fn saturating_sub(self, rhs: isize) -> isize

description: Saturating integer subtraction. Computes self - rhs, saturating at the numeric bounds instead of overflowing.

methods.name: pub fn saturating_mul(self, rhs: isize) -> isize

description: Saturating integer multiplication. Computes self * rhs, saturating at the numeric bounds instead of overflowing.

methods.name: pub fn saturating_pow(self, exp: u32) -> isize
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (no_panic_pow #48320)

methods.name: pub const fn wrapping_add(self, rhs: isize) -> isize

description: Wrapping (modular) addition. Computes self + rhs, wrapping around at the boundary of the type.

methods.name: pub const fn wrapping_sub(self, rhs: isize) -> isize

description: Wrapping (modular) subtraction. Computes self - rhs, wrapping around at the boundary of the type.

methods.name: pub const fn wrapping_mul(self, rhs: isize) -> isize

description: Wrapping (modular) multiplication. Computes self * rhs, wrapping around at the boundary of the type.

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_div(self, rhs: isize) -> isize

description: Wrapping (modular) division. Computes self / rhs, wrapping around at the boundary of the type.

The only case where such wrapping can occur is when one divides MIN / -1 on a signed type (where MIN is the negative minimal value for the type); this is equivalent to -MIN, a positive value that is too large to represent in the type. In such a case, this function returns MIN itself.
Panics
This function will panic if rhs is 0.

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_div_euc(self, rhs: isize) -> isize
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_rem(self, rhs: isize) -> isize

description: Wrapping (modular) remainder. Computes self % rhs, wrapping around at the boundary of the type.

Such wrap-around never actually occurs mathematically; implementation artifacts make x % y invalid for MIN / -1 on a signed type (where MIN is the negative minimal value). In such a case, this function returns 0.
Panics
This function will panic if rhs is 0.

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_mod_euc(self, rhs: isize) -> isize
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_neg(self) -> isize

description: Wrapping (modular) negation. Computes -self, wrapping around at the boundary of the type.

The only case where such wrapping can occur is when one negates MIN on a signed type (where MIN is the negative minimal value for the type); this is a positive value that is too large to represent in the type. In such a case, this function returns MIN itself.

methods.name: pub const fn wrapping_shl(self, rhs: u32) -> isize

description: Panic-free bitwise shift-left; yields self << mask(rhs), where mask removes any high-order bits of rhs that would cause the shift to exceed the bitwidth of the type.

Note that this is not the same as a rotate-left; the RHS of a wrapping shift-left is restricted to the range of the type, rather than the bits shifted out of the LHS being returned to the other end. The primitive integer types all implement a rotate_left function, which may be what you want instead.

methods.name: pub const fn wrapping_shr(self, rhs: u32) -> isize

description: Panic-free bitwise shift-right; yields self >> mask(rhs), where mask removes any high-order bits of rhs that would cause the shift to exceed the bitwidth of the type.

Note that this is not the same as a rotate-right; the RHS of a wrapping shift-right is restricted to the range of the type, rather than the bits shifted out of the LHS being returned to the other end. The primitive integer types all implement a rotate_right function, which may be what you want instead.

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_abs(self) -> isize

description: Wrapping (modular) absolute value. Computes self.abs(), wrapping around at the boundary of the type.

The only case where such wrapping can occur is when one takes the absolute value of the negative minimal value for the type this is a positive value that is too large to represent in the type. In such a case, this function returns MIN itself.

methods.name: pub fn wrapping_pow(self, exp: u32) -> isize
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (no_panic_pow #48320)

methods.name: pub const fn overflowing_add(self, rhs: isize) -> (isize, bool)

description: Calculates self + rhs
Returns a tuple of the addition along with a boolean indicating whether an arithmetic overflow would occur. If an overflow would have occurred then the wrapped value is returned.

methods.name: pub const fn overflowing_sub(self, rhs: isize) -> (isize, bool)

description: Calculates self - rhs
Returns a tuple of the subtraction along with a boolean indicating whether an arithmetic overflow would occur. If an overflow would have occurred then the wrapped value is returned.

methods.name: pub const fn overflowing_mul(self, rhs: isize) -> (isize, bool)

description: Calculates the multiplication of self and rhs.
Returns a tuple of the multiplication along with a boolean indicating whether an arithmetic overflow would occur. If an overflow would have occurred then the wrapped value is returned.

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_div(self, rhs: isize) -> (isize, bool)

description: Calculates the divisor when self is divided by rhs.
Returns a tuple of the divisor along with a boolean indicating whether an arithmetic overflow would occur. If an overflow would occur then self is returned.
Panics
This function will panic if rhs is 0.

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_div_euc(self, rhs: isize) -> (isize, bool)
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_rem(self, rhs: isize) -> (isize, bool)

description: Calculates the remainder when self is divided by rhs.
Returns a tuple of the remainder after dividing along with a boolean indicating whether an arithmetic overflow would occur. If an overflow would occur then 0 is returned.
Panics
This function will panic if rhs is 0.

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_mod_euc(self, rhs: isize) -> (isize, bool)
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_neg(self) -> (isize, bool)

description: Negates self, overflowing if this is equal to the minimum value.

Returns a tuple of the negated version of self along with a boolean indicating whether an overflow happened. If self is the minimum value (e.g. i32::MIN for values of type i32), then the minimum value will be returned again and true will be returned for an overflow happening.

methods.name: pub const fn overflowing_shl(self, rhs: u32) -> (isize, bool)

description: Shifts self left by rhs bits.

Returns a tuple of the shifted version of self along with a boolean indicating whether the shift value was larger than or equal to the number of bits. If the shift value is too large, then value is masked (N-1) where N is the number of bits, and this value is then used to perform the shift.

methods.name: pub const fn overflowing_shr(self, rhs: u32) -> (isize, bool)

description: Shifts self right by rhs bits.

Returns a tuple of the shifted version of self along with a boolean indicating whether the shift value was larger than or equal to the number of bits. If the shift value is too large, then value is masked (N-1) where N is the number of bits, and this value is then used to perform the shift.

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_abs(self) -> (isize, bool)

description: Computes the absolute value of self.

Returns a tuple of the absolute version of self along with a boolean indicating whether an overflow happened. If self is the minimum value (e.g. isize::MIN for values of type isize), then the minimum value will be returned again and true will be returned for an overflow happening.

methods.name: pub fn overflowing_pow(self, exp: u32) -> (isize, bool)
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (no_panic_pow #48320)

methods.name: pub fn pow(self, exp: u32) -> isize

description: Raises self to the power of exp, using exponentiation by squaring.
example:
let x: isize = 2; // or any other integer type

assert_eq!(x.pow(5), 32);

methods.name: pub fn div_euc(self, rhs: isize) -> isize
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn mod_euc(self, rhs: isize) -> isize
stability: ðŸ”¬ This is a nightly-only experimental API.  (euclidean_division #49048)

methods.name: pub fn abs(self) -> isize

description: Computes the absolute value of self.
Overflow behavior

The absolute value of isize::min_value() cannot be represented as an isize, and attempting to calculate it will cause an overflow. This means that code in debug mode will trigger a panic on this case and optimized code will return isize::min_value() without a panic.

methods.name: pub fn signum(self) -> isize

description: Returns a number representing sign of self.
0 if the number is zero 1 if the number is positive -1 if the number is negative

methods.name: pub const fn is_positive(self) -> bool

description: Returns true if self is positive and false if the number is zero or negative.

methods.name: pub const fn is_negative(self) -> bool

description: Returns true if self is negative and false if the number is zero or positive.
